choices.text: The number of transistors on a chip doubles approximately every 18-24 months
CPU clock speed doubles every year
Memory capacity increases linearly over time
Power consumption decreases exponentially

questions.prompt: The primary goal of abstraction in computer architecture is to:

choices.text: Make hardware cheaper to manufacture
Hide complexity and provide simpler interfaces at each level
Increase the clock speed of the processor
Reduce the physical size of components

questions.prompt: CPU time can be calculated as:

choices.text: Clock Rate × CPI
(Instruction Count × CPI) / Clock Rate
Instruction Count / Clock Rate
CPI × Clock Rate / Instruction Count

questions.prompt: CPI (Cycles Per Instruction) is defined as:

choices.text: Clock cycles required per instruction on average
Number of instructions executed per second
The clock frequency of the CPU
Total instruction count in a program

questions.prompt: If a program spends 40% of its time in a function that you speed up by 3×, the overall speedup is approximately:
In comparing two computers, if Computer A has a lower CPI but Computer B has a higher clock rate, which statement is true?

choices.text: Computer A is always faster
Computer B is always faster
You must calculate CPU time = (IC × CPI) / Clock Rate to determine which is faster
CPI does not affect performance
The number of tasks completed per unit time
The total time to complete a single task from start to finish
The time between interrupts
The average time for all instructions

questions.prompt: Throughput in computer performance refers to:

choices.text: The time to complete one task
The number of tasks completed per unit of time
The clock frequency of the processor
The bandwidth of the memory bus

questions.prompt: If you improve one component of a system by a factor of 10, but that component only accounts for 20% of execution time, the maximum overall speedup is:

choices.text: About 1.22×

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT a level of abstraction in computer systems?

choices.text: High-level language (e.g., C, Java)
Assembly language
Machine code (ISA)
Network protocols
